text: watch this worm turn it does that
because one of its 302 neurons is being
activated by ultrasound activating
neurons with light is a well-known
technique opto genetics but for opto
genetics you have to thread a thin
fiber-optic conduit into brain or nerve
tissue no need for that with ultrasound
and it's known to be safe researchers at
the Salk Institute and the University of
California San Diego worked with a
microscopic round worm C elegans one of
the most studied organisms in the
history of science they used microscopic
bubbles to amplify low-energy ultrasound
and they modified a single neuron so
that it was sensitive to ultrasound and
would light up when it was activated see
how bright it gets and the worm turns
around more experiments are coming up to
try the technique in mice perhaps other
animals and then
